1 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Claiming business expenses for a business with no income ### Response: Yes you can claim your business deductions if you are not making any income yet. But first you should decide what structure you want to have for your business. Either a Company structure or a Sole Trader or Partnership. If you choose a Company Structure (which is more expensive to set up) you would claim your deductions but no income. So you would be making a loss, and continue making losses until your income from the business exceed your expenses.

2 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Transferring money from One business checking to another business checking ### Response: You should have separate files for each of the two businesses. Money into your business from your personal account is probably owner's equity, unless you have something else going on. On the S Corp you should be paying yourself a salary. If you overpay by accident, then you might write a check back to the company from yourpersonal account to correct the mistake.

3 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Having a separate bank account for business/investing, but not a “business account?” ### Response: Having a separate checking account for the business makes sense. It simplifies documenting your income/expenses. If you deposit dozens of checks every time you go to the bank, the bank will want to move you to a business account. I fund IRAs and 529 plans this way.

4 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Having a separate bank account for business/investing, but not a “business account?” ### Response: You shouldn't co-mingle business expenses with personal expenses. If you buy a widget, is the widget an expense against business income? Or is it an out of pocket expense for personal consumption? If you are moving money out of the account to your personal account, that speaks to paying yourself.

5 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Having a separate bank account for business/investing, but not a “business account?” ### Response: My wife and I had his/hers/our since before we were married. I was paranoid to give out a checking account number with authorization for a third party to debit it. All this is just to explain that your finances should be arranged to simplify your life.

6 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Having a separate bank account for business/investing, but not a “business account?” ### Response: Someone had deposited a check in to my account then ran my account negative with a "dupe" of my debit card. WaMu tied up my account for three months while they investigated. Now one of the accounts contains just enough money (plus a small buffer) to pay my general monthly expenses.

7 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Business Expense - Car Insurance Deductible For Accident That Occurred During a Business Trip ### Response: As a general rule, you must choose between a mileage deduction or an actual expenses deduction. Exceptions include parking fees and tolls, which can be deducted separately. For most people, the insurance deductible just isn't large enough relative to income to be tax deductible.

9 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: “Business day” and “due date” for bills ### Response: When I deposit a check at a bank's drive-in after 4pm Friday, the receipt tells me it will credit as if I deposited on Monday. I don't believe Saturday is a business day either. If a business' computer doesn't adjust their billing to have a weekday due date, they are supposed to accept the payment on the next business day.

10 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: “Business day” and “due date” for bills ### Response: There are 2 ways for a company to mark a bill as paid. Some systems automatically assign late fees at the start of the day after the due date. For utility bills whose due date and amount can vary slightly from month to month, you're usually better off setting up your payments on the company website.

11 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: “Business day” and “due date” for bills ### Response: It's likely that your bill always shows the 24th as the due date. Their system is programmed to maintain that consistency regardless of the day of the week. If you call them and explain the situation it is likely that they will credit the late charge back to you.

If you did not elect some other tax treatment, your LLC will be treated as a partnership by the IRS. You can also elect to be taxed as an S-Corp or a C-Corp instead of a partnership.

Just have the associate sign the back and then deposit it. It's called a third party cheque and is perfectly legal. 21 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: How can I register a UK business without providing a business address? ### Response: Every company must have a registered office within the UK which is the official legal address of the company. It must be a physical address (i.e. not a PO Box without a physical location) as Companies House will use this address to send correspondence to. Your birth date will also be visible on websites which provide comapnies information.

22 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: What are 'business fundamentals'? ### Response:  fundamentals include debt, cash flow, supply of and demand for the company's   products, and so forth. For a stock the basic fundamentals are the second column of numbers you see on the google finance summary page. For the company itself it's generally the stuff on the 'financials' link.

23 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Can I send a money order from USPS as a business? ### Response: You can fill in whatever you want in the From section of a money order. The price only includes the money order itself. You can hand deliver it yourself if you want. If you want to mail it, you'll have to provide an envelope and a stamp.

24 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Business Investment Loss from prior year ### Response: In the United States, you have three years to file an amended tax return. Did the restaurant fail in 2012? If so, that's probably the year to take the loss. If you need to amend your 2012 return, which you filed in 2013, you should have until 2016 to file this.

25 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Income tax exemptions for small business? ### Response: The IRS defines “startup costs” as deductible capital expenses. These expenses can only be claimed if your research and preparation ends with the formation of a successful business. If you're a sole proprietor for tax purposes, then you'll deduct them on Schedule C of your Form 1040.

27 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: How can I estimate business taxes / filing fees for a business that has $0 income? ### Response: Is the business an S-Corp, LLC or Sole Prop? I am going to guess based on the question that it is an LLC that you never closed with the state. I am not aware of any taxes on the mere existence of a business by the IRS. I think you are going to find out that the are no taxes owed to the IRS for this nonexistent activity.

28 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: How can I estimate business taxes / filing fees for a business that has $0 income? ### Response: You need to hire a tax professional and have them sort it out for you properly. Don't do it yourself, you're way past the stage when you could. Be careful of answers like "you don't need to pay anything" that are based on nothing of facts.

29 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Would the purchase of a car for a business through the use of a business loan be considered a business expense? ### Response: The IRS has very specific rules for business use of a car. If you use the car 100% for business purposes, you NEVER use it to drive to the grocery store. You can calculate the business use by tracking the percentage of business use versus percentage of personal use.

30 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Deducting last years (undocumented) side business loss ### Response: Lack of documentation reduces your ability to prove that you're entitled to the deduction. You can not deduct it from 2012 taxes, but you can still amend 2011. Keep in mind though that amended returns have higher chance of audit, and a significant business loss on a business that only existed that year is a major red flag.

31 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: 30% share in business ### Response: Keep in mind a good lawyer will have the contract cover the five D's. Its really best to lay these things out ahead of time. I watched, first hand, two friends start a business. When they were broke and struggling the worked very well together. Then the money started rolling in.

32 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: 30% share in business ### Response: Get involved a lawyer and Accountant. Without it you may not be sure what you are getting. What exactly will 30% mean for me? It will mean exactly what gets written in contract. It can mean by current valuation, you get x fixed shares. In future if the directors creates more shares, your % ownership can get diluted.

33 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Claiming business expense from personal credit card ### Response: You should have a separate bank account and charge card for your business. There are special rules about this. Talk to your tax adviser. For the amounts in question you could probably expense it, but verify. or just input it in my accounting software along with receipts.

34 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Claiming business expense from personal credit card ### Response: There is no law that requires you to have a separate bank account for your business, or to pay all expenses from a business bank account. If you buy groceries from your business account, that's almost certainly not a deductible business expense. In your case, there are all kinds of rules about when and how much travel is deductible.

35 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Applying for and receiving business credit ### Response: The myth of limited liability companies is that all such vehicles have instant access to credit. Limited liability on a company with few physical assets to underwrite the loan, or with insufficient revenue, will usually mean that the owners will be asked to stand surety on any credit. However, there is a particular form of "credit" available to businesses on terms with their clients. It is called factoring.

36 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Applying for and receiving business credit ### Response: Banks will usually look at 2 years worth of tax returns for issuing business credit. If those aren't available, they will look at the personal returns of the owners. Alternative funding such as personal loans from family & friends could be necessary. Perhaps making them partners in exchange for capital.

37 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Using business check to pay at retail ### Response: You can just buy the items personally and then submit an expense report to the company to get reimbursed. Keep all the receipts. Paying with a company check is also fine, but you might run into problems with stores not accepting checks.

38 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Tax whilst starting a business in full time employment ### Response: With a limited company, you'll have to pay yourself a salary through PAYE. With income from your other job taking you over the higher-rate threshold, you should inform HMRC. Dividends should be like any other dividend -- you won't pay extra tax when you receive them.

39 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Do I need a business credit card? ### Response: Business credit can help build a credit score, but remember that businesses gain credit differently from individuals. Depending on the country, there isn't usually a national register of business credit ratings. Banks will usually base your business credit record on revenue and transactional loads rather than merely on having and holding a credit card.

40 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Do I need a business credit card? ### Response: I didn't want to be personally liable for the money that was spent on the business card. As I didn't fancy signing a personal guarantee, the limit was quite low. I would try to avoid mixing business expenditure with personal expenditure so a second credit card might be a good idea.

41 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Do I need a business credit card? ### Response: I would suggest at least getting a personal card that you only use for business expenses. The same goes for a checking account, if you have one of those. It makes it easier to defend if you are ever audited, and if you use an accountant or tax preparer.

This will get applied to outstanding and you will be able to spend again. However note that it generally takes 2-3 days for the credit to be applied to the card.

44 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Can I pay off my credit card balance to free up available credit? ### Response: Banks only send your balance to credit bureaus once a month; usually a few days after your statement date. As long as your usage is below 10% in that date range, you're ok. Every Sunday night, I pay our cards' charges from the previous week.

45 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Can I pay off my credit card balance to free up available credit? ### Response: If your goal is to improve your credit score I would recommend using the card, staying within your limit and pay it off every month. After 6-9 months you can probably get a bigger limit, to improveYour score. Some issuers will run a check on your creditscore that lowers it temporarily. Also: you're entitled to a free credit report each year.

If the owner is a sole-proprietor, then you'll need to track the person down and have him close the plan.

You may be better off investing in this business via a loan that's convertible to equity at your discretion. Single owner service companies are difficult because all of the net earnings go to the proprietor.

56 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Starting a large business with a not so large income?  ### Response: A startup has no prior income to use, so it must either raise money through equity or debt. Banks lend money based on the ability to pay the loan back plus interest. Equity investors are essentially the same, but since they don't get a guaranteed payback, their risk is higher.

Any income or losses will pass through to your existing income situation. The general requirement for filing as a business in this regard has nothing to do with any minimum income, revenue or size.

59 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Personal credit card for business expenses ### Response: For convenience, and the card perks, it makes sense to use the personal card. But for sake of a clean paper trail, I'd choose 1 card and use it exclusively, 100% for the business. Not one card here, one card there.

60 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Personal credit card for business expenses ### Response: I have a credit card for my single-member LLC. I prefer it this way because it makes the separation of personal and business expenses very clear. Using a personal credit card, but using it for only business expenses seems to be a reasonable practice. For your sole proprietorship, you can file a DBA which establishes the business name.

61 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Personal credit card for business expenses ### Response: You should be careful about mingling your personal money and that of the business. There's nothing illegal in what you're doing, but it would make an accountant cringe. The better habit to get into now is keeping that distinct separation between personal and business.

62 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Personal credit card for business expenses ### Response: If you are just starting out, I would say there is no disadvantage to using a personal card for business expenses. In fact, the consumer protections are better on personal cards than on business cards. Issuers expect higher charge volumes, so as your business grows might question a lot of heavy charges.

63 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: IRA for work and my business ### Response: You'll need business income to contribute to a SEP IRA though. Yes, you can have both. You'll needbusiness income to contribution to aSEP IRA however. You can't have both, but you can contribute to one if you have business income.

64 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: What are the ins/outs of writing equipment purchases off as business expenses in a home based business? ### Response: Most items used in business have to be depreciated. You get to deduct a small fraction of the cost each year depending on the lifetime of the item. With respect to consumer-type electronics such as an iPad or laptop, it helps to have a separate  item for personal use.

65 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: What are the ins/outs of writing equipment purchases off as business expenses in a home based business? ### Response: For most (big) expenses you depreciate it. In some cases you need to capitalize it, which is another accounting method. How exactly you deduct/depreciate/capitalize things depends greatly on the laws and jurisdictions. Different states have different laws, and the IRS and State laws don't have to conform.

66 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: What are the ins/outs of writing equipment purchases off as business expenses in a home based business? ### Response: Keep this rather corny acronym in mind: Business expenses must be CORN. Certain expenses that are capital items (computers, furniture, etc.) must be depreciated over several years. You have a certain amount of capital items that you can write off in the current tax year.

68 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Borrow money to invest in a business venture with equity? ### Response: Angel investing, that is to say investing in someone else's startup, is inherently risky. It's clearly a risk, but is it any different than investing in your own business? Yes, it is different. If you own a business, you determine the path of the business.

69 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: How to transfer personal auto lease to business auto lease? ### Response: If it's a new business you might not need or want the drain on your finances that a lease can be. Talk to an accountant to see if you can't just charge the business the mileage on your vehicle. Of course the mileage rate might not cover the expense for the lease.

70 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: How to transfer personal auto lease to business auto lease? ### Response: You can probably recognize most of the costs associated with the car without re-financing it in another lease. See what the contract says about transfers or subleases. A lease is a credit agreement, so the lessor may not allow transfers.

71 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Tutoring Business Payroll Management ### Response: If you collect a single check and then distribute to the tutors, you may be considered their employer. This is going to depend on the tax jurisdiction and I have no knowledge of the rules in Illinois. You would be responsible for issuing 1099 forms to anyone who goes above $600 for the year.

72 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: As a small business owner, should I pay my taxes from my personal or business checking account? ### Response: In virtually all cases LLC's are what's called a pass through entity. For these entities, all income in the eyes of the federal government passes directly through the entity to the owners at the end of each year. They are then taxed personally on this net income at their individual tax rate.

73 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Should my husband's business pay my business? ### Response: If you're not billing anything right now and may have no revenue this year, it's probably a good idea to bill his company. This is in part because some deductions or other tax treatments are only allowed if you have revenue and/or income. I don't believe you have to charge him, though, if it makes more tax sense not to.

74 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Should my husband's business pay my business? ### Response: I can think of two reasons why you might want to charge your husband. Is it worth it for me to "charge" him? Is he worth it? Do you think it's worth it to charge him? What do you think? Share your thoughts in the comments below.

75 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Should my husband's business pay my business? ### Response: I highly recommend you not charge him now. Wait until the end of the year when you have much more information about both of your companies and then you can run the numbers both ways. If either of your businesses runs on a cash basis and you decide to invoice, just make sure the check is deposited before Dec 31.

76 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Should my husband's business pay my business? ### Response: Your husband could deduct this payment as a business expense on Schedule C. If (AIUI) he will have a loss already, he'll get no benefit from this in the current year. Even if your husband can't 'use' the loss this year, he may be able to apply it in the future, when/if he has net business income.

77 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Why can't online transactions be completed outside of business hours? ### Response: The credit card company won't be able to confirm your transfer until the next business day. It may take even longer for them to actually receive the money. Unless you're doing a wire transfer, bank transactions are processed in batches overnight. So the transfer may not be confirmed until the following day.

Its a fairly simple process, and the income simply flows through to your individual return. It will allow you to deduct supplies and other expenses from that income. It should also protect you if someone sues you for doing shoddy work.
79 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: Full-time work + running small side business: Best business structure for taxes? ### Response: Error in summarization

I used to do my taxes myself, but when I created this arrangement, I started having an accountant do them. I keep a percentage in the LLC account to pay for expenses.

81 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: New vending route business, not sure how to determine taxes ### Response: You're not paying taxes three times but you are paying three different taxes (or more) Sales tax is a business expense, just like costs of goods sold or interest on a loan. Depending on how you structure the business, the net income of the business just hits you personally and you pay income taxes.

82 Below is an instruction that describes a task. ### Instruction: New vending route business, not sure how to determine taxes ### Response: As a single-owner LLC your profits (after sales taxes) should pass through to your individual tax tax return. Increasing your prices will increase your gross margins, which should be higher than your fixed and variable costs. If your margins do not exceed your costs, then you will note be profitable.
